Check for Swollen or dented cans
What action do I take if I reject an item?

What action do I take if I reject an item?

search.slidetext: an elearning sample by lloyd carew-reid march 4, 2021
food and nutrition policies for providing safe and nutritious mealsin the dhs shelter system
section 2 − deliveries and storage[for food managers and handlers]
overview delivery & storage
procedure as a trained nyc food handler you will receive and inspect food deliveries for correct temperature, quality, and quantity.

the food receiving log for every item, record compliance status and the corrective action to be taken in the food receiving log food receiving log shelter/site: date allproducts acceptable product itemtemp correctiveaction acceptableappearance(y/n) correctiveaction deliverytrucktemp correctiveaction receiveddatemarked initial
are you ready? food managers and handlers… let’s drill down on how to do this!

step 1: receiving food deliveries make sure that all food ingredients and meals received are of acceptable temperature and quality. required: you must follow the guidelines outlined in the food handler-training guide.

example soups and stews should be stored for a maximum of 4 days in a refrigerator and 3 months in a freezer. product refrigerator freezer soups & stews vegetable or meat added & mixtures of them 3 to 4 days 2 to 3 months
delivery - temperature and quality for… ambient temperature ingredients cold ingredients and meals hot meals
check for tampering delivery - ambient temperature ingredients
check for contamination delivery - ambient temperature ingredients
check for rotten or moldy fruit and vegetables delivery - ambient temperature ingredients
check for swollen or dented cans delivery - ambient temperature ingredients
cap cap corrective action plan = what action do i take if i reject an item? alert the person who orders the food to request a replacement!
delivery - temperature and quality for… ambient/room temperature ingredients cold ingredients and meals hot meals
delivery – cold ingredients and meals check the temperature of the delivery tuck when it arrives. refrigerated items must be 41°f or lower.
delivery - cold ingredients and meals take the temperature by placing the thermometer in the thickest section of the item. choose one sample of each cold item delivered.
delivery - cold ingredients and meals if the item cannot be opened/punctured (for example, vacuum-packed meat), place the thermometer between two cold items.

the food receiving log for every item, record the temperature of the cold item on the food receiving log. choose one sample of each cold item delivered. food receiving log shelter/site: date allproducts acceptable product itemtemp correctiveaction acceptableappearance(y/n) correctiveaction deliverytrucktemp correctiveaction receiveddatemarked initial
what action do i take if i reject and item? alert the person who orders the food to request a replacement!
delivery - temperature and quality for… room temperature ingredients cold ingredients and meals hot meals

delivery - hot meals do not accept any item with signs of contamination or teeth marks. do not accept any item under 140°f unless: it is time-stamped it has been out of the heat source for less than 2 hours and the facility has the proper oven to reheat the meals

the food receiving log for every item, record the temperature of the hot item on the food receiving log. choose one sample of each hot item delivered. food receiving log shelter/site: date allproducts acceptable product itemtemp correctiveaction acceptableappearance(y/n) correctiveaction deliverytrucktemp correctiveaction receiveddatemarked initial
what action do i take if i reject an item? alert the person who orders the food to request a replacement! what action do i take for items i rejected?
quantity

delivery quantity count the number of food items or meals received and check the amount is the same as the amount listed on the order slip. then, report missing items to the person in charge of ordering, or to the supervisor, to implement a cap.
step 2
step 2: storage of ingredients and meals what’s my goal? to make sure all food ingredients and prepared meals are placed in the proper storage setting as soon as the delivery is accepted.
storing ambient temperature ingredients and food items all items should be stored: at least 6 inches above the floor, and away from leaking pipes or any water.

storing cold ingredients and meals cold items are stored in refrigerators at less than or equal to 41°f or lower. all items are stored on shelves with ventilation to allow air circulation. do not stack boxes or place boxes too close to each other on the shelf.
all items are stored in accordance with food code guidelines to avoid cross-contamination. storing - cold ingredients and meals refrigerator and freezer storage chart (segment only)

refrigerator food storage chart top shelf ready-to-eat foods (including cheese, fruits and vegetables) and fully cooked foods uncooked whole fish uncooked whole cuts of beef and pork uncooked ground meats and fish bottom shelf uncooked whole and ground poultry
storing - frozen ingredients and meals you must store frozen items: in freezers at 0°f or lower. on shelves to allow airflow. at least six inches above the ground in walk-in freezers.

storing - hot meals hot items are stored in the proper hot holding unit or steam table. hot meals and meal components are held ≥ 140°f. the temperature of the hot food is checked as outlined in the temperature monitoring process.

the food receiving log for every item, record compliance status and the corrective action to be taken in the food receiving log food receiving log shelter/site: date allproducts acceptable product itemtemp correctiveaction acceptableappearance(y/n) correctiveaction deliverytrucktemp correctiveaction receiveddatemarked initial
thank you!
